conclusion: Analyze the acceleration-time graph to find velocity and position functions.
The graph shows acceleration as a function of time; acceleration changes linearly, forming a triangular waveform.
Divide the motion into three intervals: 0 to t0/2, t0/2 to t0, t0 to 2t0.
Velocity is the integral of acceleration with respect to time, starting from rest.
Calculate velocity for Interval 1: Acceleration increases linearly from 0 to a0.
Integrate acceleration to find velocity: v(t) = (a0/t0)t^2.
At t = t0/2, velocity v(t0/2) = a0 t0/4.
Calculate velocity for Interval 2: Acceleration decreases linearly from a0 to 0.
Integrate to find velocity: v(t) = a0 t0/4 + a0(t - t0/2) - (a0/t0)(t - t0/2)^2.
At t = t0, velocity v(t0) = 3a0 t0/4.
Calculate velocity for Interval 3: Acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -a0.
Integrate to find velocity: v(t) = 3a0 t0/4 - (a0/t0)(t - t0)^2.
At t = 2t0, velocity v(2t0) = 0.
Position is the integral of velocity with respect to time, starting from rest.
Calculate position for Interval 1: Integrate velocity to find position.
At t = t0/2, position x(t0/2) = a0 t0^2/24.
Calculate position for Interval 2: Integrate velocity to find position.
At t = t0, position x(t0) = a0 t0^2/6.
Calculate position for Interval 3: Integrate velocity to find position.
At t = 2t0, position x(2t0) = a0 t0^2/4.
Determine maximum distance: Particle is farthest when velocity changes from positive to negative.
